TopicTitle: Lemmy Kilmister, you will be missed!

Articles.Content:
I was saddened to hear this morning Ian “Lemmy” Kilmister has passed away.

I first saw Motorhead when I was in the Army stationed in Germany. I was absolutely blown away by their raw power.  No fancy lights or stage show, no costumes or makeup, they just came out and played hard.... so very hard!

I would argue every heavy metal band today owes their existence to Motorhead, and I hope they appreciate what Lemmy did when he started that band.  He didn't just play music, he inspired thousands, and practically invented Metal.

You will be missed....

On 12/29/2015 at 7:10 AM, Just Jim said:

I would argue every heavy metal band today owes their existence to Motörhead, and I hope they appreciate what Lemmy did when he started that band.  He didn't just play music, he inspired thousands, and practically invented Metal.

Ozzy Osbourne of Black Sabbath (and solo artist) fame, along with Billy Joe Armstrong (Green Day) both point to Lemmy as inspirations in their music, as well as (in Ozzy's case) close friends.  It's a shame that Motörhead has not been recognized in the same manner both these bands have been (R&R Hall of Fame), they (and Lemmy by proxy) are equally worthy if not moreso.  I'm sure there are also many, many more examples of bands who'd consider their music directly influenced by Lemmy.  Megadeth, Metallica (though the latter'd never admit it) and even many hard rock/metal bands of today owe at least some of their fame to what Motörhead did.

fenriz of darkthrone also credits motorhead as a major inspiration to the development of black and death metal. in fact i got into motorhead because so many other bands i liked considered them a huge influence, and now most of the music i listen to is motorhead.
